articles.title: Mali’s rural communities mobilize against child marriage in defense of girls’ futures
articles.summary: In 2018, Mali 24.1 percent of Mali's population were girls under 18 years old. More than half of them were married before the age of 18, especially in rural areas.
articles.content:
By Job Tiguem Poudiougo

Mali, home to over 25 million people, sees the majority of young women, who account for 24 percent of the population, married before they turn 18, especially in rural areas. Confronted with this stark finding, local communities are mobilizing to safeguard girls and support their continued education.

Child marriage is relatively common in Africa. Figures released in 2018 by the British NGO Girls Not Brides show that 16 percent of girls were married by the age of 15, rising to 54 percent by the age of 18, according to UNICEF. A research report from the Center for Human Rights on child marriage in Africa confirms the accuracy of these figures across ten countries on the continent, including Mali.

The rate is even higher in rural areas, driven by many factors, such as family traditions, economic hardships, and limited access to education, pushing many girls out of education and into marriages with much older men.

Furthermore, insecurity in Mali’s rural regions restricts girls’ access to schooling, with terrorist groups driving armed conflicts for the last ten years.

Read more: The Sahel faces resurgence of terrorist attacks

According to additional figures from UNICEF, 73.8 percent of girls and 85.8 percent of boys attend primary school. However, attendance drops sharply at the secondary level, with only 15 percent of girls and 21 percent of boys enrolled. Behind these statistics are shattered futures, such as Aïda D’s, who was forced into marriage at 15. She told Global Voices:

J’étais au lycée de Sévaré, une ville du centre du Mali dans la région de Mopti situé à 621 km de Bamako. Je voulais devenir professeur. Un jour, mon oncle est venu nous chercher pour aller au village. Là-bas, ma tante m’a dit que j’allais être mariée à un homme de 48 ans. Je n’ai rien dit, je pleurais. Personne ne m’a écoutée. Une semaine après, j’ai été mariée. Je ne suis jamais retournée à l’école.

I was attending high school at Sévaré, a town in the center of the country in the Mopti region, some 621 kilometers (385 miles) from Bamako, Mali’s capital. I wanted to become a teacher. One day my uncle came to fetch me and took me to the village. There, my aunt told me I was going to be married to a 48-year-old man. I did not say anything; I was crying. Nobody would listen to me. One week later I was married, and I never went back to school.

Aisha’s story, far from being an isolated case, shows how heavily traditions weigh on these communities and how young girls are forced to remain silent when confronted with decisions that derail their lives and hopes.

A ray of hope

In Mopti and elsewhere, community initiatives are beginning to address the challenge. A 2023 Facebook post by the NGO World Vision against child marriage attracted over 2,800 reactions, prompting village women and leaders to establish solidarity funds to keep girls at school.

As a result of this mobilization in Diondori, a village in the rural commune of Socoura in the Mopti Region, the committee managed to prevent 38 child marriages in 2024. This community-led initiative is part of a growing movement among Malian villages leading the fight against child marriage. Mariam Camara, the president of Diondori’s community protection committee, explained:

Nous soutenons quatre filles du village actuellement avec des kits scolaires. Nous faisons de la médiation lorsque nous apprenons qu’une famille veut marier leur fille. Garder les filles à l’école peut les préserver de beaucoup de problèmes.

We are currently helping four girls from the village with educational supply kits. We act as mediators when we learn that a family wants to marry their daughter. Keeping girls at school can shield them from many problems ahead.

Among the girls shielded by this mobilization is 14-year-old student Koumbel B, who had been promised in marriage. Her account illustrates the real difference such local initiatives can make. She said:

Il y a quelques mois, on voulait me marier de force. J'avais peur, car cela signifiait abandonner l’école et mes rêves. Mais le comité est intervenu. Ils ont parlé avec ma famille, expliqué l’importance de mon éducation, et ils m’aident encore avec les fournitures scolaires. Aujourd’hui, je suis toujours à l’école. Je rêve de devenir infirmière. Je veux dire à toutes les filles comme moi : ne perdez jamais espoir. L’école peut changer nos vies.

Some months ago, I was to be forced into marriage. I was scared because it meant saying goodbye to school and my dreams. But the committee intervened. They spoke to my family and explained how important school was. They are still helping me with school supplies and today I’m still at school. My dream is to become a nurse. I want to say to all the girls in my situation: don’t give up hope. Schools can change our lives.

For many other girls, the fight is still difficult, and its outcome may prove less favorable. Mariam Camara added:

On souhaite que nos filles puissent aller à l’école, qu’elles deviennent médecins, avocates ou encore institutrices. Les femmes ont commencé à échanger entre elles lors des tontines. Ensuite, elles ont impliqué leurs époux. Aujourd’hui, certains leaders religieux nous soutiennent.

We want our girls to go to school, for them to become doctors, lawyers or teachers. The conversations began among women during tontines [the informal savings groups common across West Africa], then extended to their husbands. Today, even some religious leaders are lending their support.

The committee is usually present on the ground at sociocultural ceremonies, raising awareness about the harms of child marriage.

From legislation to application

Beyond local initiatives, Mali has ratified several texts safeguarding children’s rights, but its Family Code, under Article 281, continues to permit marriages below the age of 18 with the consent of parents or a judge. Such exceptions, at odds with international norms, are frequently upheld by local traditions.

Organizations such as Wildaf Mali, AJM, and UNICEF are calling for reform to abolish all exceptions to the legal age of marriage, setting it strictly at 18.

Working with civil society, Malian authorities are restating their commitment to tackling the problem of child marriage. On taking office, Diarra Djeneba Sanogo, Minister for the Promotion of Women, Children, and Families, reaffirmed, on November 27, 2024, her commitment to defending children’s rights.

The movement now extends beyond the villages, reaching towns such as Mopti, with more than 330,000 inhabitants (2024), Bandiagara, 679 kilometres (420 miles) east of Bamako, with over 26,000 residents, and Koro, with a population of 25,000.

On Facebook, Wildaf Mali posted a message on December 4, 2024 denouncing child marriage (translation below):

Child marriage is a form of gender-based violence and a violation of our girls’ human rights. If we truly love them, let’s say NO to marrying our children. #NoExcuse #StopChildMarriage #NoToForcedMarriage #EducationNotMarriage

A user’s comment under the post shows just how sensitive the subject is. He posted:

Il est temps de dénoncer cette pratique, mais plusieurs couches de la société doit être impliqué dans ce processus ( les religieux, les coutumiers etc) . Si je parle trop mon compte risque d'être restreint

The time has come to call out this practice, though different sections of society need to be engaged in the process, such as religious and customary leaders. If I speak too openly, my account risks being restricted.

Younoussa Dama, local head of the Koro office for the Promotion of Women, Children and Families, who has noted progress in community engagement, explained:

Ce sont les populations elles-mêmes qui doivent être porteuses du combat. Les gens commencent à comprendre. Le discours communautaire est souvent plus influent que les lois elles-mêmes.

It is the people themselves who must carry this fight. They are beginning to understand, and community discourse is often more influential than the law itself.

The example of young Koumbel, supported by the Diondiori committee, and the voices of youth activists like Bambi Keita, show that change comes from those most directly concerned and is already under way, driven by those who refuse to remain silent.

This article was written as part of the Impact West Africa Fellowship Programme of Aspen Global Innovators.

articles.personality_title: Mali’s villages unite to stop child marriage and keep girls in school

**Context** – In Mali, a country in West Africa with over 25 million people, many girls are married before they turn 18, especially in rural areas. This is often due to traditions, poverty, and limited schooling options. Child marriage stops girls from continuing their education and affects their futures.

**What happened** – Communities in Mali, like the village of Diondori, have started to work together to prevent child marriage. In 2024, their local committee stopped 38 child marriages. They help by talking to families and providing school supplies to girls so they can stay in school. For example, 14-year-old Koumbel was saved from a forced marriage and continues to study with the committee’s support.

**Impact** – This community effort is important because it shows change can come from within the villages themselves. Families and local leaders, including some religious leaders, are joining the fight. articles.title: The missing half: The urgent need for more women’s representation in the media
articles.summary: Women make up half of the world’s population but receive only 26 per cent of media coverage, according to the latest UN-backed Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP) report, the world’s largest study on gender representation in news media.
articles.content:
“When women are missing, democracy is incomplete,” said Kirsi Madi, Assistant Secretary-General and Deputy Executive Director with the UN gender equality agency, UN Women, responding to the latest analysis.

Ms. Madi emphasised that the underrepresentation and misrepresentation of women in the media needs to be recognised as a key issue, so that democratic standards are not eroded for future generations.

Tweet URL

Seeing ourselves

UN assessments show that, despite severe restrictions on their rights in many countries, women continue to lead community initiatives, support education, and advocate for social and economic resilience under the most challenging conditions.

In Afghanistan’s Kunduz Province, *Mehrgan leads a women’s organization that once trained hundreds of women and supported local NGOs but lost much of its funding and staff in 2022.

With support from UN Women, it has since rebuilt its capacity and is now helping other women’s groups do the same.

When the media focuses only on women’s victimhood, it erases their leadership and obscures the full reality of their contributions to peace, stability, and social progress, the report highlights. Sharing stories like Mehrgan’s ensures that the public and policymakers recognize not only the challenges, but also the solutions women are driving on the ground, UN Women said.

Barriers to gender equality

Equally important is the lack of news coverage relating to gender-based violence (GBV).

Instead of challenging stereotypes, news media continue to reinforce skewed narratives such as victim-blaming typecasts, portraying GBV as isolated incidents, silencing survivor voices, and using gendered language and tropes in reports.

“Fewer than two in 100 stories cover the abuse that far too many women experience”, underscored UN Women.

Not only does severe underreporting on GBV distort reality, it also shapes public perception. Nearly four in five news stories focus on politics, the economy, or crime, leaving issues like gender-based violence underreported.

Representation is even bleaker for minority women. While individuals from racial, ethnic, religious, and other minority groups represent just six per cent of the people featured in news coverage, only 38 per cent of them are women.

The likelihood that a woman in the news is likely to be from a minority group is less than one in 10.

The way forward

Although the path to greater representation remains challenging, digital news offers a clear pathway to increased inclusion.

During the pandemic, the proportion of female online reporters increased from 25 per cent in 2015 to 42 per cent in 2020.

The UN-convened Unstereotype Alliance is a UN Women-convened initiative dedicated to eradicating harmful stereotypes in media and advertising.This along with initiatives such as the HeForShe Campaign continue to be effective vectors for promoting women’s coverage in the media and challenging stereotypes.

As the UN’s 80th General Assembly approaches, the need to reinforce gender parity and gender representation becomes even more pressing, especially considering that over the last 30 years, little to no progress has been made, said UN Women.

For more information and details, see the summary of key findings from the GMMP report here.

*Her name has been changed to protect her identity
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

articles.personality_title: UN report reveals urgent need for more women in news media
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Women make up half of the world’s population but only get about 26% of the coverage in news media. This imbalance means many women’s voices and stories are missing from public discussions.

**What happened** – A new report by the Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP), supported by the United Nations (UN), shows that women are underrepresented and often misrepresented in news stories worldwide. The report highlights examples like Mehrgan, a woman leading community work in Afghanistan, whose positive efforts are rarely covered. It also reveals that stories about gender-based violence, which affects many women, are reported very little and often in ways that blame victims or ignore survivors’ voices.

**Impact** – This lack of fair representation affects how people understand women’s roles and challenges. When media mainly show women as victims or ignore their leadership, it gives an incomplete picture and weakens democracy. Minority women are even less visible, appearing in fewer than 10% of news stories about women. The report stresses that better media coverage can help change these unfair views and support gender equality.

**What’s next step** – Digital news platforms are helping to include more women reporters, with numbers rising during the pandemic. UN campaigns like the Unstereotype Alliance and HeForShe are working to remove harmful stereotypes in media. As the UN’s 80th General Assembly approaches, there is a push to improve gender balance in news to ensure women’s stories and voices are heard more fully.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN-backed study shows that increasing women’s representation in news media is essential to reflect their true roles and support fair democratic societies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Rapport de l’ONU : un besoin urgent de plus de femmes dans les médias
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les femmes représentent la moitié de la population mondiale, mais ne bénéficient que d’environ 26 % de la couverture médiatique. Ce déséquilibre signifie que beaucoup de voix et d’histoires de femmes sont absentes des discussions publiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un nouveau rapport du Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP), soutenu par l’Organisation des Nations Unies (ONU), montre que les femmes sont sous-représentées et souvent mal représentées dans les médias du monde entier. Le rapport met en avant des exemples comme Mehrgan, une femme qui dirige un travail communautaire en Afghanistan, dont les efforts positifs sont rarement couverts. Il révèle aussi que les histoires sur la violence sexiste, qui touche de nombreuses femmes, sont très peu rapportées et souvent présentées en blâmant les victimes ou en ignorant leurs voix.

**Impact** – Ce manque de représentation juste influence la façon dont les gens perçoivent les rôles et les défis des femmes. Quand les médias montrent principalement les femmes comme des victimes ou ignorent leur leadership, ils donnent une image incomplète et affaiblissent la démocratie. Les femmes issues de minorités sont encore moins visibles, apparaissant dans moins de 10 % des histoires les concernant. Le rapport souligne que de meilleures couvertures médiatiques peuvent aider à changer ces vues injustes et soutenir l’égalité des sexes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les plateformes d’information numériques aident à inclure plus de femmes journalistes, leur nombre ayant augmenté pendant la pandémie. Des campagnes de l’ONU comme l’Alliance Unstereotype et HeForShe travaillent à éliminer les stéréotypes nuisibles dans les médias. À l’approche de la 80e Assemblée générale de l’ONU, il y a une volonté d’améliorer l’équilibre des genres dans les médias pour que les histoires et les voix des femmes soient mieux entendues.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’étude soutenue par l’ONU montre que renforcer la représentation des femmes dans les médias est essentiel pour refléter leurs vrais rôles et soutenir des sociétés démocratiques justes.
articles.personality_title_es: Informe de la ONU revela la urgente necesidad de más mujeres en los medios
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las mujeres representan la mitad de la población mundial, pero solo reciben alrededor del 26 % de la cobertura en los medios de comunicación. Este desequilibrio significa que muchas voces e historias de mujeres quedan fuera de las conversaciones públicas.

**Qué pasó** – Un nuevo informe del Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP), respaldado por las Naciones Unidas (ONU), muestra que las mujeres están subrepresentadas y a menudo mal representadas en las noticias a nivel mundial. El informe destaca ejemplos como Mehrgan, una mujer que lidera iniciativas comunitarias en Afganistán, cuyos esfuerzos positivos rara vez se cubren. También revela que las historias sobre violencia de género, que afecta a muchas mujeres, se reportan muy poco y a menudo de manera que culpan a las víctimas o silencian a las sobrevivientes.

**Impacto** – Esta falta de representación justa afecta cómo las personas entienden los roles y desafíos de las mujeres. Cuando los medios muestran a las mujeres principalmente como víctimas o ignoran su liderazgo, dan una imagen incompleta y debilitan la democracia. Las mujeres de minorías son aún menos visibles, apareciendo en menos del 10 % de las historias sobre mujeres. El informe destaca que una mejor cobertura mediática puede ayudar a cambiar estas percepciones injustas y apoyar la igualdad de género.

**Próximo paso** – Las plataformas digitales están ayudando a incluir a más mujeres periodistas, con un aumento durante la pandemia. Campañas de la ONU como la Alianza Unstereotype y HeForShe trabajan para eliminar estereotipos dañinos en los medios. Con la llegada de la 80ª Asamblea General de la ONU, se impulsa mejorar el equilibrio de género en los medios para que las historias y voces de las mujeres se escuchen más.

**Resumen en una frase** – El estudio respaldado por la ONU muestra que aumentar la representación femenina en los medios es clave para reflejar sus verdaderos roles y apoyar sociedades democráticas justas.

articles.title: Albares predicts that the agreement on Gibraltar will be drafted by the end of October and in force next year
articles.summary: The minister will appear on October 8 in Congress to explain the details.
articles.content:
Madrid – The Minister of Foreign Affairs, European Union and Cooperation, José Manuel Albares, has predicted that the agreement on Gibraltar will be drafted by the end of October and will come into effect next year, with the subsequent demolition of the Fence, once the ratification process is completed.

“The timeline we are considering, which is the one we have communicated to the European Commission, is that the agreement will be drafted by the end of October,” the minister explained in an interview on ‘RNE’, reported by Europa Press.

In this regard, he acknowledged that the “forecasts” are that the Fence will be removed next year, but it is something that “does not depend exclusively on Spain, because the Commission is the one drafting the text” and it must be ratified by both the Council and the European Parliament as well as the British one.

“The Fence will disappear. Gibraltar will be connected to both the Schengen area and the Customs Union. The controls will be carried out by both the Spanish National Police and the Spanish customs agents,” he specified, summarizing some of the key points of the agreement sealed last June between Brussels and London after more than three years of negotiation.

“We are going to have indirect tax harmonization between Gibraltar and the Campo de Gibraltar,” which represents “a real qualitative leap for the Campo de Gibraltar and a great opportunity,” he argued, also highlighting that “environmental standards will be set around European environmental standards” and that the rights of the 15,000 Spanish workers in the Rock are fully guaranteed.

Furthermore, the minister announced that he will appear on October 8 at his own request before the Plenary of the Congress of Deputies to explain the agreement. (September 4)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant diplomatic agreement that will remove physical barriers, improve cross-border cooperation, guarantee workers' rights, and harmonize environmental standards, benefiting thousands of people in the Gibraltar area and fostering regional integration.
articles.personality_title: Spain expects Gibraltar agreement by October, with border changes next year
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gibraltar is a small territory near Spain that has had a border fence separating it from Spain for many years. The fence and border controls have affected people living and working in the area.

**What happened** – Spain’s Foreign Minister, José Manuel Albares, said that a new agreement about Gibraltar will be ready by the end of October and will start being used next year. This agreement was made between the European Union and the United Kingdom after more than three years of talks.

**Impact** – The agreement will remove the fence between Gibraltar and Spain, making it easier for people to move across the border. Gibraltar will join the Schengen area, which allows passport-free travel, and the Customs Union, which simplifies trade. Spanish police and customs officers will manage border controls. The deal also protects the rights of 15,000 Spanish workers in Gibraltar and will bring environmental rules in line with European standards. This will improve life and work for many people in the region.

**What's next step** – The agreement still needs to be approved by the European Commission, the European Parliament, the Council, and the British Parliament. Minister Albares will explain the details to the Spanish Congress on October 8. Once approved, the fence will be taken down and the new border rules will start.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new agreement will soon remove the Gibraltar border fence and improve cooperation, trade, and workers' rights between Gibraltar and Spain.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Espagne prévoit un accord sur Gibraltar d’ici fin octobre, avec des changements frontaliers l’an prochain
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Gibraltar est un petit territoire près de l’Espagne, séparé par une clôture frontalière depuis de nombreuses années. Cette barrière et les contrôles ont affecté les habitants et les travailleurs de la région.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le ministre espagnol des Affaires étrangères, José Manuel Albares, a annoncé qu’un nouvel accord sur Gibraltar sera prêt d’ici fin octobre et entrera en vigueur l’an prochain. Cet accord a été négocié entre l’Union européenne et le Royaume-Uni pendant plus de trois ans.

**Impact** – L’accord prévoit la suppression de la clôture entre Gibraltar et l’Espagne, facilitant les déplacements. Gibraltar rejoindra l’espace Schengen, permettant de voyager sans passeport, et l’Union douanière, simplifiant le commerce. La police et les douanes espagnoles géreront les contrôles. Les droits des 15 000 travailleurs espagnols à Gibraltar seront protégés et les règles environnementales alignées sur les normes européennes, améliorant ainsi la vie et le travail dans la région.

**Prochaine étape** – L’accord doit encore être approuvé par la Commission européenne, le Parlement européen, le Conseil et le Parlement britannique. Le ministre Albares expliquera les détails au Congrès espagnol le 8 octobre. Une fois approuvé, la clôture sera démolie et les nouvelles règles frontalières commenceront.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouvel accord va bientôt supprimer la clôture à Gibraltar et améliorer la coopération, le commerce et les droits des travailleurs entre Gibraltar et l’Espagne.
articles.personality_title_es: España espera un acuerdo sobre Gibraltar para octubre, con cambios fronterizos el próximo año
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Gibraltar es un pequeño territorio cerca de España que ha tenido una valla fronteriza durante muchos años. Esta barrera y los controles han afectado a las personas que viven y trabajan en la zona.

**Qué pasó** – El ministro español de Asuntos Exteriores, José Manuel Albares, dijo que un nuevo acuerdo sobre Gibraltar estará listo para finales de octubre y entrará en vigor el próximo año. Este acuerdo se alcanzó entre la Unión Europea y el Reino Unido tras más de tres años de negociaciones.

**Impacto** – El acuerdo eliminará la valla entre Gibraltar y España, facilitando el paso de personas. Gibraltar se unirá al espacio Schengen, que permite viajar sin pasaporte, y a la Unión Aduanera, que simplifica el comercio. La policía y aduanas españolas harán los controles fronterizos. El acuerdo también protege los derechos de los 15,000 trabajadores españoles en Gibraltar y alineará las normas medioambientales con los estándares europeos, mejorando la vida y el trabajo en la región.

**Próximo paso** – El acuerdo debe ser aprobado por la Comisión Europea, el Parlamento Europeo, el Consejo y el Parlamento británico. El ministro Albares explicará los detalles en el Congreso español el 8 de octubre. Cuando se apruebe, se derribará la valla y comenzarán las nuevas normas fronterizas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un nuevo acuerdo eliminará pronto la valla de Gibraltar y mejorará la cooperación, el comercio y los derechos laborales entre Gibraltar y España.

articles.title: Data agreement approved by EU court
articles.summary: The USA has guaranteed an adequate level of protection for personal data transferred from the EU, according to a ruling by the EU court.
articles.content:
The USA has guaranteed an adequate level of protection for personal data transferred from the EU, according to a ruling by the EU court.

Brussels – Twice, the EU’s court has struck down the EU’s agreement on data transfer to the USA. But the third attempt has now been approved after yet another review in court.

“The USA has guaranteed an adequate level of protection for personal data transferred from the EU,” it states among other things in Wednesday’s ruling regarding the most recently agreed agreement from 2023.

The two previous agreements on the same theme were rejected in 2015 and 2020, respectively. In the third variant, however, the EU has managed to negotiate enhanced protection to prevent the misuse of European data.

(September 3)
articles.reasoning: The EU court's approval of a data transfer agreement with the USA that guarantees adequate protection of personal data represents a significant legal and human rights milestone. It ensures stronger privacy protections for millions of EU citizens' data, addressing previous concerns and enhancing cross-border data security. This ruling has broad implications for data privacy and international cooperation, benefiting the general public.
articles.personality_title: EU court approves new data protection deal with the USA
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) and the United States have been working on agreements to protect personal data when it moves between the two regions. Earlier deals were rejected by the EU court because they didn’t provide enough protection.

**What happened** – On September 3, 2024, the EU court approved the latest data transfer agreement made in 2023. This agreement means the USA now guarantees enough protection for personal data sent from the EU. This is the third time the court has reviewed these agreements, and this time the deal meets the court’s standards.

**Impact** – This approval is important because it strengthens privacy for millions of people in the EU. It ensures their personal information is safer when shared with the USA. The new rules help prevent misuse of data and improve trust between the two regions, making it easier for businesses and governments to work together.

**What's next step** – With the court’s approval, the new agreement will start being used for data transfers. Both the EU and USA will continue to monitor and enforce the rules to keep data safe. This could lead to more cooperation on data privacy and set examples for other countries.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU court’s approval of the new data deal means personal information shared with the USA is now better protected under stronger privacy rules.
articles.personality_title_fr: La cour de l’UE approuve un nouvel accord sur la protection des données avec les États-Unis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) et les États-Unis travaillent depuis plusieurs années sur des accords pour protéger les données personnelles échangées entre eux. Les accords précédents avaient été rejetés car ils n’offraient pas assez de protection.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 3 septembre 2024, la cour de l’UE a approuvé le dernier accord de transfert de données conclu en 2023. Cet accord garantit que les États-Unis protègent suffisamment les données personnelles envoyées depuis l’UE. C’est la troisième fois que la cour examine ces accords, et cette fois-ci, il respecte les exigences.

**Impact** – Cette approbation est importante car elle renforce la confidentialité pour des millions de personnes dans l’UE. Elle assure que leurs informations personnelles sont mieux protégées lorsqu’elles sont partagées avec les États-Unis. Les nouvelles règles aident à prévenir les mauvais usages et renforcent la confiance entre les deux régions, facilitant la coopération.

**Prochaine étape** – Avec cette approbation, le nouvel accord sera appliqué aux transferts de données. L’UE et les États-Unis continueront de surveiller et d’appliquer ces règles pour garantir la sécurité des données. Cela pourrait encourager plus de coopération sur la protection des données à l’avenir.

**Une phrase clé** – L’approbation de la cour de l’UE signifie que les informations personnelles partagées avec les États-Unis sont désormais mieux protégées grâce à des règles de confidentialité renforcées.
articles.personality_title_es: El tribunal de la UE aprueba un nuevo acuerdo de protección de datos con EE. UU.
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) y Estados Unidos han estado trabajando en acuerdos para proteger los datos personales que se transfieren entre ambas regiones. Los acuerdos anteriores fueron rechazados porque no ofrecían suficiente protección.

**Qué pasó** – El 3 de septiembre de 2024, el tribunal de la UE aprobó el último acuerdo de transferencia de datos firmado en 2023. Este acuerdo garantiza que Estados Unidos protege adecuadamente los datos personales enviados desde la UE. Es la tercera vez que el tribunal revisa estos acuerdos, y esta vez cumple con los estándares.

**Impacto** – Esta aprobación es importante porque fortalece la privacidad de millones de personas en la UE. Asegura que su información personal esté más segura cuando se comparte con Estados Unidos. Las nuevas reglas ayudan a evitar el mal uso de datos y mejoran la confianza entre ambas regiones, facilitando la colaboración.

**Próximo paso** – Con la aprobación del tribunal, el nuevo acuerdo comenzará a aplicarse para las transferencias de datos. La UE y EE. UU. seguirán supervisando y haciendo cumplir las normas para mantener la seguridad de los datos. Esto podría llevar a una mayor cooperación en privacidad de datos.

**Una frase clave** – La aprobación del tribunal de la UE significa que la información personal compartida con EE. UU. ahora está mejor protegida gracias a reglas de privacidad más fuertes.
